instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Hi there!
This one had a badly damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. I didn't have this exact board in stock so I used a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board instead. Replaced some of the components around it and also <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> itself. I'm starting to realise that this <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> might not be compatible with the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Is that why it's only getting 5V through USB? 0amp. 
Already replaced a couple of bad CD32s on it but no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: The <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> uses an <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> which is fairly regularly available. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> uses an <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> which is different and unfortunately can be a pain in the ass to find. These are not sold to anyone but Apple, so anything you find online either lacks firmware to make it work or is a pulled chip of unknown origin and hard to trust. Most reliable way to get one is to get your hands on a newer board that has this chip, or from a similar device that uses it (there used to be an iPhone 7 battery case you could buy for ~$70 and pull one from)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Not sure where the Aliexpress sellers found the chip sold as new.
But few friends told me such chip worked...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
thank you! found someone here that sells rebelled <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> on Ebay. Have installed it now. It's different now. 3 of the ports show 5V but are now pulsing from 0-0.04 amps

Then one of the ports is now 20V but doesn't pulse at all and shows 0 amps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
You should compare voltage and diode mode readings on the LDO lines of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Did you try DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
No sign of life on DFU
Looked at all LDO lines on all 4 chips. look good at 0.500 roughly on each line on each chip

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: strange how one port is 20V 0 amps and the other 3 are 5v and 0 - 0.04a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Do you get correct LDOs voltage on all 4 chips?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Yup. if 0.500 is correct then all 4 chips LDO lines are perfect

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Sorry, need to check voltage whoops

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Voltages correct on all 4 chips. the 1v1 lines I guess depend on the USB port that's powered. So as long as I had it in the correct port, it was perfect

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
If you get 20V in one port at least, SMC has good communication with all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
You must have problems on the input side of the ports which stay at 5V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: and the LDOs are the inputs?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
No, LDO means Low Drop OUTPUT.
Input side is related with the dual MOSFETs; like <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200, etc.
CC1/2 lines are also involved in the charger recognition.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: CD3215c006aa51pw is compatible with this board? this board has CD3215c00z98avfqwbh chips. Are these interchangeable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Because I did install two CD3215c006aa51pw chips and now im wondering if that's even correct and might be causing the issues.

I also used <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> etc. from a different board and the chip is different. I swapped them back now and I'm now getting 20V on two ports and not just one. I'm guessing there's compatibility issues here with me just randomly picking off similar chips :LOL:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: I just realised. The ports that are showing 5V are the ports that I did replace the CD32s on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Termination code is very important.
You cannot swap C00 with B03, for example.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: CC1/2 all look good in diode mode. I'm really stuck on this. Feel like it's probably some really basic shit that I'm missing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Which ports remain at 5V now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: This thing is completely trolling me. One minute a port will show 20V, the next it will show 5V, the port next to it will start the emp meter and restart the amp meter. One minute PPbus is at 3.2 the next it's at 12.2V. The ports seem to be playing musical chairs now because it's swapping which ports is displaying 20V. Very strange

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Now the port that was restarting the amp meter shows 20V... but it was stuck at 5V before....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: the other thing I find strange is that the amp meter will instantly show 20V, but on working macbooks I'm used to it going to 5V for a second and then switching to 20V after. But in this case it's instant 20v no hesitation

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: the only one that bootloops the amp meter occasionally is <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
The random behavior must be caused by corrosion.

When you connect the charger, should send 5V in the first moment.
SMC will decide to switch to 20V, usually 3-5s later.
Disconnect the battery, when you want to check the charger port behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Ok, I fixed the board. For those reading here's what caused all these very strange issues... <RESISTOR>R7990</RESISTOR> was blown. 5K ohms (supposed to be 0 ohms). Replaced that and bam! 

Thank you 2informaticos for your help!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Thanks for feedback.
Do you mean <RESISTOR>R7900</RESISTOR>?
I can't find <RESISTOR>R7990</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Whoops, that's the one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Crap, Touch Bar doesn't work on this. :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
You should test with known good touchbar; its one may be damaged by liquid spill.
Also inspect touchbar flex and MLB connector for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Will it just work out the box or will it have to be reset and all that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: New one should work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message: Just tested new Touch Bar and doesn't work

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Did you check MLB connectors?
Need to measure some voltage and signals; with touchbar connected, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="kevinklinkmuller, post: 85646, member: 511"]
Ok, I fixed the board. For those reading here's what caused all these very strange issues... <RESISTOR>R7990</RESISTOR> was blown. 5K ohms (supposed to be 0 ohms). Replaced that and bam!

Thank you 2informaticos for your help!
[/QUOTE]

How did you spot it? Did it have a visual change or indications? It's on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> line

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="it-solve, post: 85867, member: 25485"]
How did you spot it? Did it have a visual change or indications? It's on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> line
[/QUOTE]


Visual, it was pretty lucky. Was frustrated with the board. Could't find anything wrong so I checked basically every component under the scope. This one was brown

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 85800, member: 682"]
Did you check MLB connectors?
Need to measure some voltage and signals; with touchbar connected, of course.
[/QUOTE]


Ended up being a burn mark on L5111, replaced and Touch Bar is back WOOOO

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> area. 5V 0amp USB
threads.message:
Thanks for feedback.
It helps us to understand what kind of failure components can cause touchbar issues.
